title: I took part in an all-female race – but should they still exist in 2019?
text:
It’s race day. Windsor Castle stands tall in the background as Cyndi Lauper’s Girls Just Want To Have Fun booms out the speakers. I feel like I’m in an 80s-style aerobics class, as I stand near the start line and warm up by doing jumping jacks alongside 1,500 other women.

I specify women because this is the Windsor Women’s 10km event – the only men here are the ones lining the sides of the race to offer support.

We’ve been longing for gender parity in running for decades, ever since Kathrine Switzer became the first woman to run the Boston marathon in 1967 (officials were so incensed they tried to grab her bib number off her); and it's worth remembering that the women's marathon was only added...
